Communication-Computation Efficient
Secure Aggregation for Federated Learning

Beongjun Choi  ,   Jy-yong Sohn*, Dong-Jun Han and Jaekyun Moon
School of Electrical Engineering
Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (KAIST)
{bbzang10, jysohn1108, djhan93}@kaist.ac.kr, jmoon@kaist.edu
Both authors contributed equally to this work.
Abstract

Federated learning has been spotlighted as a way to train neural networks using distributed data with no need for individual nodes to share data. Unfortunately, it has also been shown that adversaries may be able to extract local data contents off model parameters transmitted during federated learning. A recent solution based on the secure aggregation primitive enabled privacy-preserving federated learning, but at the expense of significant extra communication/computational resources. In this paper, we propose a low-complexity scheme that provides data privacy using substantially reduced communication/computational resources relative to the existing secure solution. The key idea behind the suggested scheme is to design the topology of secret-sharing nodes as a sparse random graph instead of the complete graph corresponding to the existing solution. We first obtain the necessary and sufficient condition on the graph to guarantee both reliability and privacy. We then suggest using the Erdős-Rényi graph in particular and provide theoretical guarantees on the reliability/privacy of the proposed scheme. Through extensive real-world experiments, we demonstrate that our scheme, using only 20∼30%similar-to20percent3020\sim 30\% of the resources required in the conventional scheme, maintains virtually the same levels of reliability and data privacy in practical federated learning systems.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (McMahan et al., 2017) has been considered as a promising framework for training models in a decentralized manner without explicitly sharing the local private data. This framework is especially useful in various predictive models which learn from private distributed data, e.g., healthcare services based on medical data distributed over multiple organizations (Brisimi et al., 2018; Xu & Wang, 2019) and text prediction based on the messages of distributed clients (Yang et al., 2018; Ramaswamy et al., 2019). In the federated learning (FL) setup, each device contributes to the global model update by transmitting its local model only; the private data is not shared across the network, which makes FL highly attractive (Kairouz et al., 2019; Yang et al., 2019).

Unfortunately, however, FL could still be vulnerable against the adversarial attacks on the data leakage. Specifically, the local model transmitted from a device contains extensive information on the training data, and an eavesdropper can estimate the data owned by the target device (Fredrikson et al., 2015; Shokri et al., 2017; Melis et al., 2019). Motivated by this issue, the authors of (Bonawitz et al., 2017) suggested secure aggregation (SA), which integrates cryptographic primitives into the FL framework to protect data privacy. However, SA requires significant amounts of additional resources on communication and computing for guaranteeing privacy. Especially, the communication and computation burden of SA increases as a quadratic function of the number of clients, which limits the scalability of SA.

Contributions

We propose communication-computation efficient secure aggregation (CCESA) algorithm, which maintains the reliability and data privacy in federated learning with reduced resources on communication and computation compared to conventional secure aggregation of (Bonawitz et al., 2017). The key idea is to replace the complete graph topology of (Bonawitz et al., 2017) with a low-degree graph for resource efficiency, as illustrated in Fig. 1. Under the threat of eavesdroppers, we first provide the necessary and sufficient condition on the sparse graph topology for private and reliable secure aggregation and suggest an explicit graph design rule based on a conceptually simple Erdos-Renyi graph. As a consequence, the required resources of the proposed CCESA reduce by a factor of at least O​(n/log⁡n)𝑂𝑛𝑛O(\sqrt{n/\log n}) compared to (Bonawitz et al., 2017). Here, we acknowledge that parallel work (Bell et al., 2020) utilizes a Harary graph topology where each client more effectively selects the clients sharing its secret, and consequently further reduces communication/computation costs of secure aggregation. Detailed comparisons are given in Table 1. Our mathematical results are also confirmed in experiments on two real datasets of AT&T face database and CIFAR-10, under practical attack scenarios including the model inversion attack and the membership inference attack. Especially, under the model inversion attack on the face dataset, the results in Fig. 2 show that the suggested scheme achieves near-perfect data privacy by using less amount of resources than SA, while federated averaging without security measures (McMahan et al., 2017) significantly compromises the privacy of the data.

Related work

Focusing on the collaborative learning setup with multiple clients and a server, previous works have suggested solutions to prevent the information leakage in the communication links between the server and clients. One major approach utilizes the concept of differential privacy (DP) (Dwork et al., 2014) by adding artificial random noise to the transmitted models (Wei et al., 2020; Geyer et al., 2017; Truex et al., 2020) or gradients (Shokri & Shmatikov, 2015; Abadi et al., 2016; Balcan et al., 2012). Depending on the noise distribution, DP-based collaborative learning generally exhibits a trade-off between the privacy level and the convergence of the global model.

Another popular approach is deploying secure multiparty computation (MPC)  (Ben-Or et al., 1988; Damgård et al., 2012; Aono et al., 2017; Lindell et al., 2015; Bonawitz et al., 2017; Zhang et al., 2018; Tjell & Wisniewski, 2019; Shen et al., 2020; So et al., 2020) based on the cryptographic primitives including secret sharing and the homomorphic encryption (Leontiadis et al., 2014; 2015; Shi et al., 2011; Halevi et al., 2011). Although these schemes guarantee privacy, they suffer from high communication burdens while reconstructing the secret information distributed over multiple clients. A notable work (Bonawitz et al., 2017) suggested secure aggregation (SA), which tolerates multiple client failures by applying pairwise additive masking (Ács & Castelluccia, 2011; Elahi et al., 2014; Jansen & Johnson, 2016; Goryczka & Xiong, 2015). A recent work (So et al., 2020) suggested Turbo-aggregate, an approach based on the circular aggregation topology to achieve a significant computation/communication complexity reduction in secure aggregation. However, each client in Turbo-aggregate requires a communication cost of at least 4​m​n​R/L4𝑚𝑛𝑅𝐿4mnR/L bits, which is much larger than that of our scheme (CCESA) requiring a communication cost of n​log⁡n​(2​aK+5​aS)+m​R𝑛𝑛2subscript𝑎𝐾5subscript𝑎𝑆𝑚𝑅\sqrt{n\log n}(2a_{K}+5a_{S})+mR111Here, m𝑚m is the number of model parameters where each parameter is represented in R𝑅R bits. L𝐿L is the number of client groups in Turbo-aggregate. aKsubscript𝑎𝐾a_{K} and aSsubscript𝑎𝑆a_{S} are the number of bits required for exchanging public keys and the number of bits in a secret share, respectively.. For example, in a practical scenario with m=106,R=32,n=100,L=10formulae-sequence𝑚superscript106formulae-sequence𝑅32formulae-sequence𝑛100𝐿10m=10^{6},R=32,n=100,L=10 and aK=aS=256subscript𝑎𝐾subscript𝑎𝑆256a_{K}=a_{S}=256, our scheme requires only 3%percent33\% of the communication bandwidth used in Turbo-aggregate.

The idea of replacing the complete graph with a low-degree graph for communication efficiency has been studied in the areas of distributed learning (Charles et al., 2017; Sohn et al., 2020) and multi-party computation (Fitzi et al., 2007; Harnik et al., 2007). Very recently, the authors of (Bell et al., 2020) independently suggested using sparse graphs for reducing the communication/computation overhead in the secure aggregation framework of (Bonawitz et al., 2017). Both CCESA and the parallel work of (Bell et al., 2020) utilize selective secret sharing across a subset of client pairs, and design a sparse graph topology. Under an honest-but-curious attack setup, (Bell et al., 2020) uses the Harary graph topology and realizes an excellent efficiency, achieving polylogarithmic communication/computation complexity per client.

Cryptographic primitives for preserving privacy

Here we review three cryptographic tools used in SA (Bonawitz et al., 2017). First, t𝑡t-out-of-n𝑛n secret sharing (Shamir, 1979) is splitting a secret s𝑠s into n𝑛n shares, in a way that any t𝑡t shares can reconstruct s𝑠s, while any t−1𝑡1t-1 shares provides absolutely no information on s𝑠s. We denote t𝑡t-out-of-n𝑛n secret sharing by s→(t,n)(sk)k∈[n],𝑡𝑛→𝑠subscriptsubscript𝑠𝑘𝑘delimited-[]𝑛s\xrightarrow{(t,n)}(s_{k})_{k\in[n]}, where sksubscript𝑠𝑘s_{k} indicates the kthsuperscript𝑘thk^{\text{th}} share of secret s𝑠s and [n]delimited-[]𝑛[n] represents the index set {1,2,⋯,n}12⋯𝑛\{1,2,\cdots,n\}. Second, the Diffie-Hellman key agreement is used to generate a secret si,jsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑗s_{i,j} that is only shared by two target clients i,j∈[n]𝑖𝑗delimited-[]𝑛i,j\in[n]. The key agreement scheme designs public-private key pairs (suP​K,suS​K)superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑢𝑃𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑢𝑆𝐾(s_{u}^{PK},s_{u}^{SK}) for clients u∈[n]𝑢delimited-[]𝑛u\in[n] in a way that si,j=f​(siP​K,sjS​K)=f​(sjP​K,siS​K)subscript𝑠𝑖𝑗𝑓superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑃𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑗𝑆𝐾𝑓superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑗𝑃𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑆𝐾s_{i,j}=f({s_{i}^{PK},s_{j}^{SK}})=f({s_{j}^{PK},s_{i}^{SK}}) holds for all i,j∈[n]𝑖𝑗delimited-[]𝑛i,j\in[n] for some key agreement function f𝑓f. The secret si,jsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑗s_{i,j} is unknown when neither siS​Ksuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑆𝐾s_{i}^{SK} nor sjS​Ksuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑗𝑆𝐾s_{j}^{SK} is provided. Third, symmetric authenticated encryption is encrypting/decrypting message m𝑚m using a key k𝑘k shared by two target clients. This guarantees the integrity of the messages communicated by the two clients.

Secure aggregation (Bonawitz et al., 2017)

For privacy-preserving federated learning, SA has been proposed based on the cryptographic primitives of Shamir’s secret sharing, key agreement and symmetric authenticated encryption. The protocol consists of four steps: Step 0 Advertise Keys, Step 1 Share Keys, Step 2 Masked Input Collection, and Step 3 Unmasking.

3 Suggested algorithm

In the secure aggregation (Bonawitz et al., 2017), the public keys (ciP​K,siP​K)superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑖𝑃𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑃𝐾(c_{i}^{PK},s_{i}^{PK}) and the shares of secrets (siS​K,bi)superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑆𝐾subscript𝑏𝑖(s_{i}^{SK},b_{i}) are transmitted between clients and the server, which requires additional communication/computational resources compared with the vanilla federated learning. Specifically, since each client i𝑖i needs to receive information from all other clients j≠i𝑗𝑖j\neq i, the required amount of resources increases as a quadratic function of the number of clients n𝑛n.

In this paper, we suggest a variant of secure aggregation, dubbed as communication-computation efficient secure aggregation (CCESA), which enables to provide a more scalable solution for privacy-preserving federated learning by improving the communication/computational efficiency. The basic idea of the proposed algorithm is to allow each client to share its public keys and secret shares to a subset of other clients, instead of sharing them with all other clients. By doing so, compared with SA, the suggested scheme achieves two advantages in resource efficiency, without losing the reliability of learning algorithms and the data privacy. The first advantage is the reduction of the communication cost, since each node shares its public keys and secrets with less clients. The second advantage is a reduction of the computational cost of each client, since a smaller number of masks are used while computing its masked private vector.

The proposed algorithm is specified by the assignment graph which represents how public keys and secret shares are assigned to the other clients. Given n𝑛n clients, the assignment graph G=(V,E)𝐺𝑉𝐸G=(V,E) consists of n𝑛n vertices where the vertex and the edge set of G𝐺G are represented by V𝑉V and E𝐸E, respectively. We set V=[n]𝑉delimited-[]𝑛V=[n] where each index i∈V𝑖𝑉i\in V represents client i𝑖i, and the edge {i,j}∈E𝑖𝑗𝐸\{i,j\}\in E connecting vertices i𝑖i and j𝑗j indicates that client i𝑖i and j𝑗j exchange their public keys and secret shares. For vertex i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n], we define A​d​j​(i):={j;{i,j}∈E}assign𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖𝑗𝑖𝑗𝐸Adj(i):=\big{\{}j;\{i,j\}\in E\big{\}} as the index set of vertices adjacent to vertex i𝑖i. In our algorithm, public keys and secrets of client i𝑖i are shared with clients j∈A​d​j​(i)𝑗𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖j\in Adj(i).

Now, using the assignment graph notation, we formally provide the suggested algorithm in Algorithm 1. Here we summarize the differences compared to SA. and transmits θ~isubscript~𝜃𝑖\tilde{\theta}_{i} to the server. Note that the suggested protocol with n𝑛n-complete assignment graph G𝐺G reduces to SA.

Here we define several notations representing the evolution of the assignment graph G𝐺G as some of the nodes may drop out of the system in each step. Recall that V0=Vsubscript𝑉0𝑉V_{0}=V and Vi+1subscript𝑉𝑖1V_{i+1} is defined as the set of survived nodes in Step i∈{0,⋯,3}𝑖0⋯3i\in\{0,\cdots,3\}. Let us define Gisubscript𝐺𝑖G_{i} as the induced subgraph of G𝐺G whose vertex set is Visubscript𝑉𝑖V_{i}, i.e., Gi:=G−(V\Vi)assignsubscript𝐺𝑖𝐺\𝑉subscript𝑉𝑖G_{i}:=G-(V\backslash V_{i}). Then, Gi+1subscript𝐺𝑖1G_{i+1} represents how the non-failed clients are connected in Step i𝑖i. We define the evolution of assignment graph during the protocol as 𝑮=(G0,G1,⋯,G4)𝑮subscript𝐺0subscript𝐺1⋯subscript𝐺4\bm{G}=(G_{0},G_{1},\cdots,G_{4}).

In Fig. 1, we illustrate an example of the suggested algorithm with n=5𝑛5n=5 clients. Fig. 1a corresponds to SA (Bonawitz et al., 2017), while Fig. 1b depicts the proposed scheme. Here, we focus on the required communication/computational resources of client 1. Note that each client exchanges public keys and secret shares with its adjacent clients. For example, client 1 exchanges the data with four other clients in the conventional scheme, while client 1 exchanges the data with clients 3 and 5 in the suggested scheme. Thus, the proposed CCESA requires only half of the bandwidth compared to the conventional scheme. In addition, CCESA requires less computational resources than conventional scheme, since each client generates less secret shares and pseudo-random values, and performs less key agreements.

4 Theoretical analysis

4.1 Performance metrics

The proposed CCESA algorithm aims at developing private, reliable and resource-efficient solutions for federated learning. Here, we define key performance metrics for federated learning systems including federated averaging (McMahan et al., 2017), SA (Bonawitz et al., 2017) and CCESA. Recall that the server receives (masked) model parameters θ~isubscript~𝜃𝑖\tilde{\theta}_{i} from clients i∈V3𝑖subscript𝑉3i\in V_{3}, and wants to update the global model as the sum of the unmasked model parameters, i.e., θglobal←∑i∈V3θi←subscript𝜃globalsubscript𝑖subscript𝑉3subscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{\text{global}}\leftarrow\sum_{i\in V_{3}}\theta_{i}. The condition for successful (or reliable) global model update is stated as follows.

Definition 1.

A system is called reliable if the server successfully obtains the sum of the model parameters ∑i∈V3θisubscript𝑖subscript𝑉3subscript𝜃𝑖\sum_{i\in V_{3}}\theta_{i} aggregated over the distributed clients.

Now, we define the notion of privacy in the federated learning. We assume that the server and the clients participating in the system are trusted, and consider the threat of an eavesdropper who can access any information (namely, public keys of clients, secret shares, masked local models and the indices of surviving clients V3subscript𝑉3V_{3}) transmitted between clients and the server during the execution of CCESA algorithm.

Once an eavesdropper gets the local model θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i} of client i𝑖i, it can reconstruct the private data (e.g., face image or medical records) of the client or can identify the client which contains the target data. In general, if an eavesdropper obtains the sum of local models occupied by a subset 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} of clients, a similar privacy attack is possible for the subset of clients. Thus, to preserve the data privacy, it is safe to protect the information on the partial sum of model parameters against the eavesdropper; we formalize this.

Definition 2.

A system is called private if I​(∑i∈𝒯θi;E)=0𝐼subscript𝑖𝒯subscript𝜃𝑖𝐸0I(\sum_{i\in\mathcal{T}}\theta_{i};E)=0, i.e., H​(∑i∈𝒯θi)=H​(∑i∈𝒯θi|E)𝐻subscript𝑖𝒯subscript𝜃𝑖𝐻conditionalsubscript𝑖𝒯subscript𝜃𝑖𝐸H(\sum_{i\in\mathcal{T}}\theta_{i})=H(\sum_{i\in\mathcal{T}}\theta_{i}|E) holds for all 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} satisfying 𝒯⊂V3𝒯subscript𝑉3\mathcal{T}\subset V_{3} and 𝒯∉{∅,V3}𝒯subscript𝑉3\mathcal{T}\notin\{\varnothing,V_{3}\}. Here, H𝐻H is the entropy function, I​(X;Y)𝐼𝑋𝑌I(X;Y) is the mutual information between X𝑋X and Y𝑌Y, and E𝐸E is the information accessible to the eavesdropper.

When both reliability and privacy conditions hold, the server successfully updates the global model, while an eavesdropper cannot extract data in the information-theoretic sense. We define Pe(r)superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑒𝑟P_{e}^{(r)} and Pe(p)superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑒𝑝P_{e}^{(p)} as the probabilities that reliability and privacy conditions do not hold, respectively.

4.2 Results for general assignment graph G𝐺G

Recall that our proposed scheme is specified by the assignment graph G𝐺G. We here provide mathematical analysis on the performance metrics of reliability and privacy, in terms of the graph G𝐺G. To be specific, the theorems below provide the necessary and sufficient conditions on the assignment graph G𝐺G to enable reliable/private federated learning, where the reliability and privacy are defined in Definitions 1 and 2. Before going into the details, we first define informative nodes as below.

Definition 3.

A node i∈V0𝑖subscript𝑉0i\in V_{0} is called informative when |(A​d​j​(i)∪{i})∩V4|≥ti𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖𝑖subscript𝑉4subscript𝑡𝑖|(Adj(i)\cup\{i\})\cap V_{4}|\geq t_{i} holds.

Note that node i𝑖i is called informative when the server can reconstruct the secrets (bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i} or siS​Ksuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑆𝐾s_{i}^{SK}) of node i𝑖i in Step 3 of the algorithm. Using this definition, we state the condition on graph G𝐺G for enabling reliable systems as below.

Theorem 1.

The system is reliable if and only if node i𝑖i in informative for all i∈V3+𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑉3i\in V_{3}^{+}, where V3+=V3∪{i∈V2:A​d​j​(i)∩V3≠∅}superscriptsubscript𝑉3subscript𝑉3conditional-set𝑖subscript𝑉2𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖subscript𝑉3V_{3}^{+}=V_{3}\cup\{i\in V_{2}:Adj(i)\cap V_{3}\neq\varnothing\} is the union of V3subscript𝑉3V_{3} and the neighborhoods of V3subscript𝑉3V_{3} within V2subscript𝑉2V_{2}.

Proof.

The full proof is given in Appendix B.1 ; here we provide a sketch for the proof. Recall that the server receives the sum of masked models ∑i∈V3θ~isubscript𝑖subscript𝑉3subscript~𝜃𝑖\sum_{i\in V_{3}}\tilde{\theta}_{i}, while the system is said to be reliable if the server obtains the sum of unmasked models ∑i∈V3θisubscript𝑖subscript𝑉3subscript𝜃𝑖\sum_{i\in V_{3}}\theta_{i}. Thus, the reliability condition holds if and only if the server can cancel out the random terms in (4), which is possible when either siS​Ksuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑆𝐾s_{i}^{SK} or bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i} is recovered for all i∈V3+𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑉3i\in V_{3}^{+}. Since a secret is recovered if and only if at least tisubscript𝑡𝑖t_{i} shares are gathered from adjacent nodes, we need |(A​d​j​(i)∪{i})∩V4|≥ti𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖𝑖subscript𝑉4subscript𝑡𝑖|(Adj(i)\cup\{i\})\cap V_{4}|\geq t_{i}, which completes the proof. ∎

Now, before moving on to the next theorem, we define some sets of graph evolutions as below:

𝒢Csubscript𝒢C\displaystyle\mathcal{G}_{\text{C}}\ ={𝑮=(G0,G1,⋯,G4):G3​ is connected },absentconditional-set𝑮subscript𝐺0subscript𝐺1⋯subscript𝐺4subscript𝐺3 is connected \displaystyle=\{\bm{G}=(G_{0},G_{1},\cdots,G_{4}):G_{3}\text{ is connected }\},
𝒢Dsubscript𝒢D\displaystyle\mathcal{G}_{\text{D}}\ ={𝑮=(G0,G1,⋯,G4):G3​ is not connected },absentconditional-set𝑮subscript𝐺0subscript𝐺1⋯subscript𝐺4subscript𝐺3 is not connected \displaystyle=\{\bm{G}=(G_{0},G_{1},\cdots,G_{4}):G_{3}\text{ is not connected }\},
𝒢NI subscript𝒢NI \displaystyle\mathcal{G}_{\text{NI }}\ ={𝑮∈𝒢D:∀l∈[κ],∃i∈Cl+​ such that node ​i​ is not informative}.absentconditional-set𝑮subscript𝒢Dformulae-sequencefor-all𝑙delimited-[]𝜅𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑙 such that node 𝑖 is not informative\displaystyle=\{\bm{G}\in\mathcal{G}_{\text{D}}:\forall l\in[\kappa],\exists i\in C_{l}^{+}\text{ such that node }i\text{ is not informative}\}.

Here, when G3subscript𝐺3G_{3} is a disconnected graph with κ≥2𝜅2\kappa\geq 2 components, Clsubscript𝐶𝑙C_{l} is defined as the vertex set of the lthsuperscript𝑙thl^{\text{th}} component, and Cl+:=Cl∪{i∈V2:A​d​j​(i)∩Cl≠∅}assignsuperscriptsubscript𝐶𝑙subscript𝐶𝑙conditional-set𝑖subscript𝑉2𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖subscript𝐶𝑙C_{l}^{+}:=C_{l}\cup\{i\in V_{2}:Adj(i)\cap C_{l}\neq\varnothing\}. Using this definition, we state a sufficient condition on the assignment graph to enable private federated learning.

Lemma 1.

The system is private if 𝐆∈𝒢C𝐆subscript𝒢𝐶\bm{G}\in\mathcal{G}_{C}.

Proof.

Again we just provide a sketch of the proof here; the full proof is in Appendix B.2. Note that G3subscript𝐺3G_{3} is the induced subgraph of G𝐺G whose vertex set is V3subscript𝑉3V_{3}. Suppose an eavesdropper has access to the masked local models {θ~i}i∈𝒯subscriptsubscript~𝜃𝑖𝑖𝒯\{\tilde{\theta}_{i}\}_{i\in\mathcal{T}} of a subset 𝒯⊂V3𝒯subscript𝑉3\mathcal{T}\subset V_{3} of nodes. Now, the question is whether this eavesdropper can recover the sum of the unmasked models ∑i∈𝒯θisubscript𝑖𝒯subscript𝜃𝑖\sum_{i\in\mathcal{T}}\theta_{i}. If G3subscript𝐺3G_{3} is connected, there exists an edge e={p,q}𝑒𝑝𝑞e=\{p,q\} such that p∈𝒯𝑝𝒯p\in\mathcal{T} and q∈V3\𝒯𝑞\subscript𝑉3𝒯q\in V_{3}\backslash\mathcal{T}. Note that ∑i∈𝒯θ~isubscript𝑖𝒯subscript~𝜃𝑖\sum_{i\in\mathcal{T}}\tilde{\theta}_{i} contains the PRG​(sp,q)PRGsubscript𝑠𝑝𝑞\textbf{PRG}(s_{p,q}) term, while sp,qsubscript𝑠𝑝𝑞s_{p,q} is not accessible by the eavesdropper since p,q∈V3𝑝𝑞subscript𝑉3p,q\in V_{3}. Thus, from (4), the eavesdropper cannot obtain ∑i∈𝒯θisubscript𝑖𝒯subscript𝜃𝑖\sum_{i\in\mathcal{T}}\theta_{i}, which completes the proof. ∎

Based on the Lemma above, we state the necessary and sufficient condition for private system as below, the proof of which is given in Appendix B.3.

Theorem 2.

The system is private if and only if 𝐆∈𝒢C∪𝒢N​I𝐆subscript𝒢𝐶subscript𝒢𝑁𝐼\bm{G}\in\mathcal{G}_{C}\cup\mathcal{G}_{NI}.

The theorems above provide guidelines on how to construct the assignment graph G𝐺G to enable reliable and private federated learning. These guidelines can be further specified when we use the Erdős-Rényi graph as the assignment graph G𝐺G. In the next section, we explore how the Erdős-Rényi graph can be used for reliable and private federated learning.

4.3 Results for Erdős-Rényi assignment graph G𝐺G

The Erdős-Rényi graph G∈G​(n,p)𝐺𝐺𝑛𝑝G\in G(n,p) is a random graph of n𝑛n nodes where each edge connecting two arbitrary nodes is connected with probability p𝑝p. Define CCESA(n,p𝑛𝑝n,p) as the proposed scheme using the assignment graph of G∈G​(n,p)𝐺𝐺𝑛𝑝G\in G(n,p). According to the analysis provided in this section, CCESA(n,p𝑛𝑝n,p) almost surely achieves both reliability and privacy conditions, provided that the connection probability p𝑝p is chosen appropriately. Throughout the analysis below, we assume that each client independently drops out with probability q𝑞q at each step (from Step 0 to Step 4), and the secret sharing parameter tisubscript𝑡𝑖t_{i} is set to t𝑡t for all i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n].

4.3.1 For asymptotically large n𝑛n

We start with the analysis on CCESA(n,p𝑛𝑝n,p) when n𝑛n is asymptotically large. The following two theorems provide lower bounds on p𝑝p to satisfy reliability/privacy conditions. The proofs are provided in Appendix B.4 and B.5.

Theorem 3.

CCESA(n,p𝑛𝑝n,p) is asymptotically almost surely reliable if p>3​(n−1)​log⁡(n−1)−1(n−1)​(2​(1−q)4−1).𝑝3𝑛1𝑛11𝑛12superscript1𝑞41p>\frac{3\sqrt{(n-1)\log(n-1)}-1}{(n-1)(2(1-q)^{4}-1)}.

Theorem 4.

CCESA(n,p𝑛𝑝n,p) is asymptotically almost surely private if p>log⁡(⌈n​(1−q)3−n​log⁡n⌉)⌈n​(1−q)3−n​log⁡n⌉.𝑝𝑛superscript1𝑞3𝑛𝑛𝑛superscript1𝑞3𝑛𝑛p>\frac{\log(\lceil n(1-q)^{3}-\sqrt{n\log n}\rceil)}{\lceil n(1-q)^{3}-\sqrt{n\log n}\rceil}.

From these theorems, the condition for achieving both reliability and privacy is obtained as follows.

Remark 1.

Let

p⋆=max⁡{log⁡(⌈n​(1−q)3−n​log⁡n⌉)⌈n​(1−q)3−n​log⁡n⌉,3​(n−1)​log⁡(n−1)−1(n−1)​(2​(1−q)4−1)}.superscript𝑝⋆𝑛superscript1𝑞3𝑛𝑛𝑛superscript1𝑞3𝑛𝑛3𝑛1𝑛11𝑛12superscript1𝑞41{p^{\star}=\max\{\frac{\log(\lceil n(1-q)^{3}-\sqrt{n\log n}\rceil)}{\lceil n(1-q)^{3}-\sqrt{n\log n}\rceil},\frac{3\sqrt{(n-1)\log(n-1)}-1}{(n-1)(2(1-q)^{4}-1)}\}.} (5)

If p>p⋆𝑝superscript𝑝⋆p>p^{\star}, then CCESA(n,p𝑛𝑝n,p) is asymptotically almost surely (a.a.s.) reliable and private. Note that the threshold connection probability p⋆superscript𝑝⋆p^{\star} is a decreasing function of n𝑛n. Thus, the proposed algorithm is getting more resource efficient than SA as n𝑛n grows, improving the scalability of the system.

In the remarks below, we compare SA and the proposed CCESA, in terms of the required amount of communication/computational resources to achieve both reliability and privacy. These results are summarized in Table 1.

Remark 2.

Let B𝐵B be the amount of additional communication bandwidth used at each client, compared to that of federated averaging (McMahan et al., 2017). Since the bandwidth is proportional to n​p𝑛𝑝np, we have BC​C​E​S​A​(n,p)∼O​(n​log⁡n)similar-tosubscript𝐵𝐶𝐶𝐸𝑆𝐴𝑛𝑝𝑂𝑛𝑛B_{CCESA(n,p)}\sim O(\sqrt{n\log n}) and BS​A∼O​(n)similar-tosubscript𝐵𝑆𝐴𝑂𝑛B_{SA}\sim O(n). Thus, the suggested CCESA protocol utilizes a much smaller bandwidth compared to SA in  (Bonawitz et al., 2017). The detailed comparison is given in Appendix C.1.

Remark 3.

Compared to SA, the proposed CCESA algorithm generates a smaller number of secret shares and pseudo-random values, and performs less key agreements. Thus, the computational burden at the server and the clients reduces by a factor of at least O​(n/log⁡n)𝑂𝑛𝑛O(\sqrt{n/\log n}). The detailed comparison is given in Appendix C.2.

4.3.2 For finite n𝑛n

We now discuss the performance of the suggested scheme for finite n𝑛n. Let Pe(p)superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑒𝑝P_{e}^{(p)} be the error probability that CCESA(n,p𝑛𝑝n,p) does not satisfy the the privacy condition, and define Pe(p)superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑒𝑝P_{e}^{(p)} as the error probability that CCESA(n,p𝑛𝑝n,p) is not reliable. Below we provide upper bounds on Pe(p)superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑒𝑝P_{e}^{(p)} and Pe(r)superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑒𝑟P_{e}^{(r)}.

Theorem 5.

For arbitrary n,p,q𝑛𝑝𝑞n,p,q and t𝑡t, the error probability for reliability Pe(r)superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑒𝑟P_{e}^{(r)} is bounded by Pe(r)≤n​e−(n−1)DK​L(t−1n−1||p(1−q)4),P_{e}^{(r)}\leq ne^{-(n-1)D_{KL}(\frac{t-1}{n-1}||p(1-q)^{4})}, where DK​Lsubscript𝐷𝐾𝐿D_{KL} is the Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence.

Theorem 6.

For arbitrary n,p𝑛𝑝n,p and q𝑞q, the error probability for privacy Pe(p)superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑒𝑝P_{e}^{(p)} is bounded by

Pe(p)≤∑m=0n(nm)​(1−q)3​m​(1−(1−q)3)(n−m)​∑k=1⌊m/2⌋(mk)​(1−p)k​(m−k).superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑒𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑚0𝑛binomial𝑛𝑚superscript1𝑞3𝑚superscript1superscript1𝑞3𝑛𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑚2binomial𝑚𝑘superscript1𝑝𝑘𝑚𝑘P_{e}^{(p)}\leq\sum_{m=0}^{n}{n\choose m}(1-q)^{3m}(1-(1-q)^{3})^{(n-m)}\sum_{k=1}^{\lfloor m/2\rfloor}{m\choose k}(1-p)^{k(m-k)}.

Fig. 4.1 illustrates the upper bounds on Pe(p)superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑒𝑝P_{e}^{(p)} and Pe(r)superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑒𝑟P_{e}^{(r)} obtained in Theorems 5 and 6, when p=p⋆𝑝superscript𝑝⋆p=p^{\star}. Here, qtotal:=1−(1−q)4assignsubscript𝑞total1superscript1𝑞4q_{\text{total}}:=1-(1-q)^{4} is defined as the dropout probability of the entire protocol (from Step 0 to Step 4). Note that the upper bounds in Theorems 5 and 6 are decreasing functions of p𝑝p. Therefore, the plotted values in Fig. 4.1 are indeed upper bounds on the error probabilities for arbitrary p>p⋆𝑝superscript𝑝⋆p>p^{\star}. It is shown that a system with the suggested algorithm is private and reliable with high probability for an arbitrary chosen p>p⋆𝑝superscript𝑝⋆p>p^{\star}. The error probability for the privacy Pe(p)superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑒𝑝P_{e}^{(p)} is below 10−40superscript104010^{-40}, which is negligible even for small n𝑛n. The error probability for the reliability Pe(r)superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑒𝑟P_{e}^{(r)} is below 10−2superscript10210^{-2}, which means that in at most one round out of 100 federated learning rounds, the (masked) models {θ~i}i∈V3subscriptsubscript~𝜃𝑖𝑖subscript𝑉3\{\tilde{\theta}_{i}\}_{i\in V_{3}} received by the server cannot be converted to the sum of (unmasked) local models ∑i∈V3θisubscript𝑖subscript𝑉3subscript𝜃𝑖\sum_{i\in V_{3}}\theta_{i}. Even in this round when the server cannot obtain the sum of (unmasked) local models, the server is aware of the fact that the current round is not reliable, and may maintain the global model used in the previous round. This does not harm the accuracy of our scheme, as shown in the experimental results of Section 5.

5 Experiments

Here we provide experimental results on the proposed CCESA algorithm. We compare CCESA and secure aggregation (SA) of (Bonawitz et al., 2017) in terms of time complexity (running time), reliability, and privacy. We tested both schemes on two real datasets, AT&T Laboratories Cambridge database of faces (https://www.kaggle.com/kasikrit/att-database-of-faces) and CIFAR-10. For the AT&T face dataset containing images of 40 individuals, we considered a federated learning setup where each of n=40𝑛40n=40 clients uses its own images for local training. All algorithms are implemented in python and PyTorch (Paszke et al., 2017). Codes will be made available to the public.

5.1 Running time

In Table 5.1, we tested the running time of our CCESA and existing SA for various n𝑛n and qtotalsubscript𝑞totalq_{\text{total}}. Similar to the setup used in (Bonawitz et al., 2017), we assumed that each node has its local model 𝜽𝜽\bm{\theta} with dimension m=10000𝑚10000m=10000, where each element of the model is chosen from the field 𝔽216subscript𝔽superscript216\mathbb{F}_{2^{16}}. Here, t𝑡t is selected by following the guideline in Appendix E, and p𝑝p is chosen as p⋆∼O​(log⁡n/n)similar-tosuperscript𝑝⋆𝑂𝑛𝑛p^{\star}\sim O(\sqrt{\log n/n}) defined in (5) which is proven to meet both reliability and privacy conditions. For every n,qtotal𝑛subscript𝑞totaln,q_{\text{total}} setup, the proposed CCESA(n,p𝑛𝑝n,p) requires p𝑝p times less running time compared with the conventional SA of (Bonawitz et al., 2017). This is because each client generates p𝑝p times less number of secret shares and pseudo-random values, and performs p𝑝p times less number of key agreements. This result is consistent with our analysis on the computational complexity in Table 1.

5.2 Reliability

Recall that a system is reliable if the server obtains the sum of the local models ∑i∈V3θisubscript𝑖subscript𝑉3subscript𝜃𝑖\sum_{i\in V_{3}}\theta_{i}. Fig. 5.2 shows the reliability of CCESA in CIFAR-10 dataset. We plotted the test accuracies of SA and the suggested CCESA(n,p𝑛𝑝n,p) for various p𝑝p. Here, we included the result when p=p⋆=0.3106𝑝superscript𝑝⋆0.3106p=p^{\star}=0.3106, where p⋆superscript𝑝⋆p^{\star} is the provably minimum connection probability for achieving both the reliability and privacy according to Remark 1. One can confirm that CCESA with p=p⋆𝑝superscript𝑝⋆p=p^{\star} achieves the performance of SA in both i.i.d. and non-i.i.d. data settings, coinciding with our theoretical result in Theorem 3. Moreover, in both settings, selecting p=0.25𝑝0.25p=0.25 is sufficient to achieve the test accuracy performance of SA when the system is trained for 200200200 rounds. Thus, the required communication/computational resources for guaranteeing the reliability, which is proportional to n​p𝑛𝑝np, can be reduced to 25%percent2525\% of the conventional wisdom in federated learning. Similar behaviors are observed from the experiments on AT&T Face dataset, as in Appendix A.1.

5.3 Privacy

We first consider a privacy threat called model inversion attack (Fredrikson et al., 2015). The basic setup is as follows: the attacker eavesdrops the masked model θ~isubscript~𝜃𝑖\tilde{\theta}_{i} sent from client i𝑖i to the server, and reconstructs the face image of a target client. Under this setting, we compared how the eavesdropped model reveals the information on the raw data for various schemes. As in Fig. 2 and Fig. A.4 in Appendix A.2, the vanilla federated averaging (McMahan et al., 2017) with no privacy-preserving techniques reveals the characteristics of individual’s face, compromising the privacy of clients. On the other hand, both SA and CCESA do not allow any clue on the client’s face; these schemes are resilient to the model inversion attack and preserve the privacy of clients. This observation is consistent with our theoretical results that the proposed CCESA guarantees data privacy. We also considered another privacy threat called the membership inference attack (Shokri et al., 2017). Here, the attacker eavesdrops the masked model θ~isubscript~𝜃𝑖\tilde{\theta}_{i} and guesses whether a target data is a member of the training dataset. Table 5.2 summarizes the accuracy of the inference attack for CIFAR-10 dataset, under the federated learning setup where ntrainsubscript𝑛trainn_{\text{train}} training data is equally distributed into n=10𝑛10n=10 clients. The attack accuracy reaches near 70%percent7070\% for federated averaging, while SA and CCESA have the attack accuracy of near 50%percent5050\%, similar to the performance of the random guess.

6 Conclusion

We devised communication-computation efficient secure aggregation (CCESA) which successfully preserves the data privacy of federated learning in a highly resource-efficient manner. Based on graph-theoretic analysis, we showed that the amount of communication/computational resources can be reduced at least by a factor of n/log⁡n𝑛𝑛\sqrt{n/\log n} relative to the existing secure solution without sacrificing data privacy. Our experiments on real datasets, measuring the test accuracy and the privacy leakage, show that CCESA requires only 20∼30%similar-to20percent3020\sim 30\% of resources than the conventional wisdom, to achieve the same level of reliability and privacy.

Appendix A Additional experimental results

A.1 Reliability

In Fig. 5.2 of the main paper, we provided the experimental results on the reliaiblity of CCESA on CIFAR-10 dataset. Similarly, Fig. A.3 shows the reliability of CCESA in AT&T Face dataset, where the model is trained over n=40𝑛40n=40 clients. We plotted the test accuracies of SA and the suggested CCESA(n,p𝑛𝑝n,p) for various p𝑝p. In both settings of qtotalsubscript𝑞totalq_{\text{total}}, selecting p=0.7𝑝0.7p=0.7 is sufficient to achieve the test accuracy performance of SA when the system is trained for 505050 rounds. Thus, the required communication/computational resources for guaranteeing the reliability, which is proportional to n​p𝑛𝑝np, can be reduced to 70%percent7070\% of the conventional wisdom in federated learning.

A.2 Privacy

In Section 5.3 and Fig. 2 of the main paper, we provided the experimental results on the AT&T Face dataset, under the model inversion attack. In Fig. A.4, we provide additional experimental results on the same dataset for different participants. Similar to the result in Fig. 2, the model inversion attack successfully reveals the individuals identity in federated averaging (McMahan et al., 2017), while the privacy attack is not effective in both SA and the suggested CCESA.

In Section 5.3, we have also considered another type of privacy threat called membership inference attack (Shokri et al., 2017), where the attacker observes masked local model θ~isubscript~𝜃𝑖\tilde{\theta}_{i} sent from client i𝑖i to the server, and guesses whether a particular data is the member of the training set. We measured three types of performance metrics of the attacker: accuracy (the fraction of the records correctly estimated the membership), precision (the fraction of the responses inferred as members of the training dataset that are indeed members) and recall (the fraction of the training data that the attacker can correctly infer as members). Table 5.2 summarizes the attack accuracy result, while Table A.3 shows the attack precision for CIFAR-10 dataset. We also observed that recall is close to 111 for all schemes. Similar to the results on the attack accuracy, Table A.3 shows that the attack precision of federated averaging reaches near 70%percent7070\%, while that of SA and CCESA remain around the baseline performance of random guess. This shows that both SA and CCESA do not reveal any clue on the training set.

Therefore, the server cannot compute ∑i∈V3θisubscript𝑖subscript𝑉3subscript𝜃𝑖\sum_{i\in V_{3}}\theta_{i}, which completes the proof.

B.2 Proof of Lemma 1

Proof.

Let 𝒯⊂V3𝒯subscript𝑉3\mathcal{T}\subset V_{3} be an arbitrary set of clients satisfying 𝒯∉{∅,V3}𝒯subscript𝑉3\mathcal{T}\notin\{\varnothing,V_{3}\}. It is sufficient to prove the following statement: given a connected graph G3subscript𝐺3G_{3}, an eavesdropper cannot obtain the partial sum of local models ∑i∈𝒯θisubscript𝑖𝒯subscript𝜃𝑖\sum_{i\in\mathcal{T}}\theta_{i} from the sum of masked models ∑i∈𝒯θ~isubscript𝑖𝒯subscript~𝜃𝑖\sum_{i\in\mathcal{T}}\tilde{\theta}_{i}. More formally, we need to prove

B.3 Proof of Theorem 2

Proof.

We first prove that the system is private if 𝑮∈𝒢C∪𝒢N​I𝑮subscript𝒢𝐶subscript𝒢𝑁𝐼\bm{G}\in\mathcal{G}_{C}\cup\mathcal{G}_{NI}. When 𝑮∈𝒢C𝑮subscript𝒢𝐶\bm{G}\in\mathcal{G}_{C}, the statement holds directly from Lemma 1. Thus, below we only prove for the case of 𝑮∈𝒢N​I𝑮subscript𝒢𝑁𝐼\bm{G}\in\mathcal{G}_{NI}. Note that it is sufficient to prove the following statement: given a graph evolution 𝑮=(G0,G1,⋯,G4)∈𝒢N​I𝑮subscript𝐺0subscript𝐺1⋯subscript𝐺4subscript𝒢𝑁𝐼\bm{G}=(G_{0},G_{1},\cdots,G_{4})\in\mathcal{G}_{NI}, an eavesdropper cannot obtain the partial sum of local models ∑i∈𝒯θisubscript𝑖𝒯subscript𝜃𝑖\sum_{i\in\mathcal{T}}\theta_{i} from the sum of masked models ∑i∈𝒯θ~isubscript𝑖𝒯subscript~𝜃𝑖\sum_{i\in\mathcal{T}}\tilde{\theta}_{i} for every 𝒯⊂V3𝒯subscript𝑉3\mathcal{T}\subset V_{3} satisfying 𝒯∉{V3,∅}𝒯subscript𝑉3\mathcal{T}\notin\{V_{3},\varnothing\}. More formally, we need to prove

H​(∑i∈𝒯θi|∑i∈𝒯θ~i)=H​(∑i∈𝒯θi).𝐻conditionalsubscript𝑖𝒯subscript𝜃𝑖subscript𝑖𝒯subscript~𝜃𝑖𝐻subscript𝑖𝒯subscript𝜃𝑖H(\sum_{i\in\mathcal{T}}\theta_{i}|\sum_{i\in\mathcal{T}}\tilde{\theta}_{i})=H(\sum_{i\in\mathcal{T}}\theta_{i}). (7)

When 𝒯=Cl𝒯subscript𝐶𝑙\mathcal{T}=C_{l} for some l∈[κ]𝑙delimited-[]𝜅l\in[\kappa], there exists i⋆∈Cl+superscript𝑖⋆superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑙i^{\star}\in C_{l}^{+} such that node i𝑖i is not informative, according to the definition of 𝒢N​Isubscript𝒢𝑁𝐼\mathcal{G}_{NI}. Thus, the server (as well as eavesdroppers) cannot reconstruct both bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i} and siS​Ksuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑆𝐾s_{i}^{SK}. Note that the sum of masked models is

∑i∈𝒯θ~i=∑i∈𝒯θi+∑i∈𝒯PRG​(bi)+∑j∈𝒯∑i∈V2∪A​d​j​(j)(−1)𝟙j>i​PRG​(sj,i),subscript𝑖𝒯subscript~𝜃𝑖subscript𝑖𝒯subscript𝜃𝑖subscript𝑖𝒯PRGsubscript𝑏𝑖subscript𝑗𝒯subscript𝑖subscript𝑉2𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑗superscript1subscript1𝑗𝑖PRGsubscript𝑠𝑗𝑖\sum_{i\in\mathcal{T}}\tilde{\theta}_{i}=\sum_{i\in\mathcal{T}}\theta_{i}+\sum_{i\in\mathcal{T}}\textbf{PRG}(b_{i})+\sum_{j\in\mathcal{T}}\sum_{i\in V_{2}\cup Adj(j)}(-1)^{\mathds{1}_{j>i}}\textbf{PRG}(s_{j,i}), (8)

where 𝟙Asubscript1𝐴\mathds{1}_{A} is the indicator function which is value 111 when the statement A𝐴A is true, and 00 otherwise. When i⋆∈Cl=𝒯superscript𝑖⋆subscript𝐶𝑙𝒯i^{\star}\in C_{l}=\mathcal{T}, we cannot unmask PRG​(bi⋆)PRGsubscript𝑏superscript𝑖⋆\textbf{PRG}(b_{i^{\star}}) in this equation. When i⋆∈Cl+\Clsuperscript𝑖⋆\superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑙subscript𝐶𝑙i^{\star}\in C_{l}^{+}\backslash C_{l}, there exists j∈Cl𝑗subscript𝐶𝑙j\in C_{l} such that {i⋆,j}∈Esuperscript𝑖⋆𝑗𝐸\{i^{\star},j\}\in E. Thus, the eavesdropper cannot unmask PRG​(sj,i⋆)PRGsubscript𝑠𝑗superscript𝑖⋆\textbf{PRG}(s_{j,i^{\star}}) from (8). Now, we prove the converse by contrapositive: if 𝑮=(G0,G1,⋯,G4)∈𝒢D∩𝒢N​Ic𝑮subscript𝐺0subscript𝐺1⋯subscript𝐺4subscript𝒢𝐷superscriptsubscript𝒢𝑁𝐼𝑐\bm{G}=(G_{0},G_{1},\cdots,G_{4})\in\mathcal{G}_{D}\cap\mathcal{G}_{NI}^{c}, then the system is not private. where

𝐳=𝐳absent\displaystyle\mathbf{z}= ∑i∈𝒯∑j∈V2∩A​d​j​(i)(−1)𝟙i>j​PRG​(si,j)=(a)∑i∈𝒯∑j∈𝒯(−1)𝟙i>j​PRG​(si,j)=(b)0.superscript𝑎subscript𝑖𝒯subscript𝑗subscript𝑉2𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖superscript1subscript1𝑖𝑗PRGsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑗subscript𝑖𝒯subscript𝑗𝒯superscript1subscript1𝑖𝑗PRGsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑗superscript𝑏0\displaystyle\sum_{i\in\mathcal{T}}\sum_{j\in V_{2}\cap Adj(i)}(-1)^{\mathds{1}_{i>j}}\textbf{PRG}(s_{i,j})\stackrel{{\scriptstyle(a)}}{{=}}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{T}}\sum_{j\in\mathcal{T}}(-1)^{\mathds{1}_{i>j}}\textbf{PRG}(s_{i,j})\stackrel{{\scriptstyle(b)}}{{=}}0.

Note that (a)𝑎(a) holds since 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} is a component, (b)𝑏(b) holds from si,j=sj,isubscript𝑠𝑖𝑗subscript𝑠𝑗𝑖s_{i,j}=s_{j,i}. Moreover, the eavesdropper can reconstruct bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i} for all i∈𝒯𝑖𝒯i\in\mathcal{T} in Step 3 of the algorithm. Thus, the eavesdropper can successfully unmask random terms in ∑i∈𝒯θ~isubscript𝑖𝒯subscript~𝜃𝑖\sum_{i\in\mathcal{T}}\tilde{\theta}_{i} and obtain ∑i∈𝒯θisubscript𝑖𝒯subscript𝜃𝑖\sum_{i\in\mathcal{T}}\theta_{i}. B.4 Proof of Theorem 3

Proof.

Consider Erdős-Rényi assignment graph G∈G​(n,p)𝐺𝐺𝑛𝑝G\in G(n,p). Let Ni:=|A​d​j​(i)|assignsubscript𝑁𝑖𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖N_{i}:=|Adj(i)| be the degree of node i𝑖i, and Xi:=|A​d​j​(i)∩V4|assignsubscript𝑋𝑖𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖subscript𝑉4X_{i}:=|Adj(i)\cap V_{4}| be the number of clients (except client i𝑖i) that successfully send the shares of client i𝑖i to the server in Step 3. Then, Nisubscript𝑁𝑖N_{i} and Xisubscript𝑋𝑖X_{i} follow the binomial distributions

For a given p>t+(n−1)​log⁡(n−1)(n−1)​(1−q)4𝑝𝑡𝑛1𝑛1𝑛1superscript1𝑞4p>\frac{t+\sqrt{(n-1)\log(n-1)}}{(n-1)(1-q)^{4}}, we obtain

∎

Appendix C Required resources of CCESA

C.1 Communication cost

Here, we derive the additional communication bandwidth BCCESAsubscript𝐵CCESAB_{\text{CCESA}} used at each client for running CCESA, compared to the bandwidth used for running federated averaging (McMahan et al., 2017). We consider the worst-case scenario having the maximum additional bandwidth, where no client fails during the operation.

The required communication bandwidth of each client is composed of four parts. First, in Step 0, each client i𝑖i sends two public keys to the server, and receives 2​|A​d​j​(i)|2𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖2|Adj(i)| public keys from other clients. Second, in Step 1, each client i𝑖i sends encrypted 2​|A​d​j​(i)|2𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖2|Adj(i)| shares to other nodes, and receives 2​|A​d​j​(i)|2𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖2|Adj(i)| shares from other nodes through the server. Third, in Step 2, each client i𝑖i sends a masked data yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} of m​R𝑚𝑅mR bits. Here, m𝑚m is the dimension of model parameters where each parameter is represented in R𝑅R bits. Fourth, in Step 3, each client i𝑖i sends |A​d​j​(i)|+1𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖1|Adj(i)|+1 shares to the server. Therefore, total communication bandwidth of client i𝑖i can be expressed as

(total communication bandwidth)=2​(|A​d​j​(i)|+1)​aK+(5​|A​d​j​(i)|+1)​aS+m​R,total communication bandwidth2𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖1subscript𝑎𝐾5𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖1subscript𝑎𝑆𝑚𝑅(\text{total communication bandwidth})=2(|Adj(i)|+1)a_{K}+(5|Adj(i)|+1)a_{S}+mR,

where aKsubscript𝑎𝐾a_{K} and aSsubscript𝑎𝑆a_{S} are the number of bits required for exchanging public keys and the number of bits in a secret share. Since each client i𝑖i requires m​R𝑚𝑅mR bits to send the private vector θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i} in the federated averaging (McMahan et al., 2017), we have

BCCESA=2​(|A​d​j​(i)|+1)​aK+(5​|A​d​j​(i)|+1)​aS.subscript𝐵CCESA2𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖1subscript𝑎𝐾5𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖1subscript𝑎𝑆B_{\text{CCESA}}=2(|Adj(i)|+1)a_{K}+(5|Adj(i)|+1)a_{S}.

If we choose the connection probability p=(1+ϵ)​p⋆𝑝1italic-ϵsuperscript𝑝⋆p=(1+\epsilon)p^{\star} for a small ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0, we have BCCESA=O​(n​log⁡n)subscript𝐵CCESA𝑂𝑛𝑛B_{\text{CCESA}}=O(\sqrt{n\log n}), where p⋆superscript𝑝⋆p^{\star} is defined in (5). Note that the additional bandwidth BSAsubscript𝐵SAB_{\text{SA}} required for SA can be similarly obtained as BS​A=2​n​aK+(5​n−4)​aSsubscript𝐵𝑆𝐴2𝑛subscript𝑎𝐾5𝑛4subscript𝑎𝑆B_{SA}=2na_{K}+(5n-4)a_{S} having BSA=O​(n)subscript𝐵SA𝑂𝑛B_{\text{SA}}=O(n). Thus, we have

BCCESABSA→0→subscript𝐵CCESAsubscript𝐵SA0\displaystyle\frac{B_{\text{CCESA}}}{B_{\text{SA}}}\rightarrow 0

as n𝑛n increases, showing the scalability of CCESA. These results are summarized in Table 1.

C.2 Computational cost

We evaluate the computational cost of CCESA. Here we do not count the cost for computing the signatures since it is negligible. First, we derive the computational cost of each client. Given the number of model parameters m𝑚m and the number of clients n𝑛n, the computational cost of client i𝑖i is composed of three parts: (1) computing 2​|A​d​j​(i)|2𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖2|Adj(i)| key agreements, which takes O​(|A​d​j​(i)|)𝑂𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖O(|Adj(i)|) time, (2) generating shares of tisubscript𝑡𝑖t_{i}-out-of-|A​d​j​(i)|𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖|Adj(i)| secret shares of siS​Ksuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑆𝐾s_{i}^{SK} and bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i}, which takes O​(|A​d​j​(i)|2)𝑂superscript𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖2O(|Adj(i)|^{2}) time, and (3) generating masked local model θ~isubscript~𝜃𝑖\tilde{\theta}_{i}, which requires O​(m​|A​d​j​(i)|)𝑂𝑚𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖O(m|Adj(i)|) time. Thus, the total computational cost of each client is obtained as O​(|A​d​j​(i)|2+m​|A​d​j​(i)|)𝑂superscript𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖2𝑚𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖O(|Adj(i)|^{2}+m|Adj(i)|). Second, the server’s computational cost is composed of two parts: (1) reconstructing tisubscript𝑡𝑖t_{i}-out-of-|A​d​j​(i)|𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖|Adj(i)| secrets from shares for all clients i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n], which requires O​(n​|A​d​j​(i)|2)𝑂𝑛superscript𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖2O(n|Adj(i)|^{2}) time, and (2) removing masks from masked sum of local models ∑i=1nθ~isuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript~𝜃𝑖\sum_{i=1}^{n}\tilde{\theta}_{i}, which requires O​(m​|A​d​j​(i)|2)𝑂𝑚superscript𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖2O(m|Adj(i)|^{2}) time in the worst case. As a result, the total computational cost of the server is O​(m​|A​d​j​(i)|2)𝑂𝑚superscript𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖2O(m|Adj(i)|^{2}). If we choose p=(1+ϵ)​p⋆𝑝1italic-ϵsuperscript𝑝⋆p=(1+\epsilon)p^{\star} for small ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0, the total computational cost per each client is O​(n​log⁡n+m​n​log⁡n)𝑂𝑛𝑛𝑚𝑛𝑛O(n\log n+m\sqrt{n\log n}), while the total computation cost of the server is O​(m​n​log⁡n+n2​log⁡n)𝑂𝑚𝑛𝑛superscript𝑛2𝑛O(mn\log n+n^{2}\log n). The computational cost of SA can be obtained in a similar manner, by setting A​d​j​(i)=n−1𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖𝑛1Adj(i)=n-1; each client requires O​(n2+m​n)𝑂superscript𝑛2𝑚𝑛O(n^{2}+mn) time while the server requires O​(m​n2)𝑂𝑚superscript𝑛2O(mn^{2}) time. These results are summarized in Table 1.

=\displaystyle= Θ​(log⁡n/n),Θ𝑛𝑛\displaystyle\Theta(\sqrt{\log n/n}),

Appendix E Designing the parameter t𝑡t for the secret sharing

Here we provide a rule for selecting parameter t𝑡t used in the secret sharing. In general, setting t𝑡t to a smaller number is better for tolerating dropout scenarios. However, when t𝑡t is excessively small, the system is vulnerable to the unmasking attack of adversarial server; the server may request shares of bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i} and siS​Ksuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑆𝐾s_{i}^{SK} to disjoint sets of remaining clients simultaneously, which reveals the local model θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i} to the server. The following proposition provides a rule of designing parameter t𝑡t to avoid such unmasking attack.

Proposition 1 (Lower bound on t𝑡t).

For CCESA(n,p𝑛𝑝n,p), let t>(n−1)​p+(n−1)​log⁡(n−1)+12𝑡𝑛1𝑝𝑛1𝑛112t>\frac{(n-1)p+\sqrt{(n-1)\log(n-1)}+1}{2} be given. Then, the system is asymptotically almost surely secure against the unmasking attack.

Proof.

Let E𝐸E be the event that at least one of local models are revealed to the server, and Eisubscript𝐸𝑖E_{i} be the event that ithsuperscript𝑖thi^{\text{th}} local model θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i} is revealed to the server. Note that θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i} is revealed to the server if t𝑡t clients send the shares of bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i} and other t𝑡t clients send the shares of siS​Ksuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑆𝐾s_{i}^{SK} in Step 3. Therefore,

P​(Ei)𝑃subscript𝐸𝑖\displaystyle P(E_{i}) ≤P​(|(A​d​j​(i)∪{i})∩V4|≥2​t)absent𝑃𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖𝑖subscript𝑉42𝑡\displaystyle\leq P(|(Adj(i)\cup\{i\})\cap V_{4}|\geq 2t)
≤P(|(Adj(i)∪{i})|≥2t)=P(|(Adj(i)|≥2t−1)\displaystyle\leq P(|(Adj(i)\cup\{i\})|\geq 2t)=P(|(Adj(i)|\geq 2t-1)
≤P​(|A​d​j​(i)|>(n−1)​p+(n−1)​log⁡(n−1))≤(a)1(n−1)2,absent𝑃𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖𝑛1𝑝𝑛1𝑛1superscript𝑎1superscript𝑛12\displaystyle\leq P(|Adj(i)|>(n-1)p+\sqrt{(n-1)\log(n-1)})\stackrel{{\scriptstyle(a)}}{{\leq}}\frac{1}{(n-1)^{2}},

where (a) comes from Hoeffding’s inequality of binomial random variable. As a result, we obtain

P​(E)=P​(∪i∈[n]Ei)≤∑i∈[n]P​(Ei)=n​P​(E1)=n(n−1)2→n→∞0,𝑃𝐸𝑃subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝐸𝑖subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛𝑃subscript𝐸𝑖𝑛𝑃subscript𝐸1𝑛superscript𝑛12→𝑛→0P(E)=P(\cup_{i\in[n]}E_{i})\leq\sum_{i\in[n]}P(E_{i})=nP(E_{1})=\frac{n}{(n-1)^{2}}\xrightarrow{n\rightarrow\infty}0,

which completes the proof. ∎

As stated above, setting t𝑡t to a smaller number is better to tolerate the dropout of multiple clients. Thus, as in the following remark, we set t𝑡t to be the minimum value avoiding the unmasking attack.

Remark 4 (Design rule for t𝑡t).

Throughout the paper, we set t=⌈(n−1)​p+(n−1)​log⁡(n−1)+12⌉𝑡𝑛1𝑝𝑛1𝑛112t=\lceil\frac{(n-1)p+\sqrt{(n-1)\log(n-1)}+1}{2}\rceil for CCESA(n,p𝑛𝑝n,p), in order to secure a system against the unmasking attack and provide the maximum tolerance against dropout scenarios.

Appendix F Detailed experimental setup

F.1 AT & T face dataset

AT&T Face dataset contains images of 404040 members. We allocated the data to n=40𝑛40n=40 clients participating in the federated learning, where each client contains the images of a specific member. This experimental setup is suitable for the practical federated learning scenario where each client has its own image and the central server aggregates the local models for face recognition. Following the previous work (Fredrikson et al., 2015) on the model inversion, we used softmax regression for the classification. Both the number of local training epochs and the number of global aggregation rounds are set to El​o​c​a​l=Eg​l​o​b​a​l=50subscript𝐸𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑎𝑙subscript𝐸𝑔𝑙𝑜𝑏𝑎𝑙50E_{local}=E_{global}=50, and we used the SGD optimizer with learning rate γ=0.05𝛾0.05\gamma=0.05.

F.2 CIFAR-10 dataset

F.2.1 Reliability experiment in Fig. 5.2

We ran experiments under the federated learning setup where 500005000050000 training images are allocated to n=1000𝑛1000n=1000 clients. Here, we considered two scenarios for data allocation: one is partitioning the data in the i.i.d. manner (i.e., each client randomly obtains 505050 images), while the other is non-i.i.d. allocation scenario. For the non-i.i.d. scenario, we followed the procedure of (McMahan et al., 2017). Specifically, the data is first sorted by its category, and then the sorted data is divided into 200020002000 shards. Each client randomly chooses 2 shards for its local training data. Since each client has access to at most 2 classes, the test accuracy performance is degraded compared with the i.i.d. setup. For training the classifier, we used VGG-11 network and the SGD optimizer with learning rate γ=0.1𝛾0.1\gamma=0.1 and momentum β=0.5𝛽0.5\beta=0.5. The local training epoch is set to El​o​c​a​l=3subscript𝐸𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑎𝑙3E_{local}=3.

F.2.2 Privacy experiments in Table 5.2 and Table A.3

We conducted experiments under the federated learning setup where ntrainsubscript𝑛trainn_{\text{train}} training images are assigned to n=10𝑛10n=10 clients. We considered i.i.d. data allocation setup where each client randomly obtains ntrain/10subscript𝑛train10n_{\text{train}}/10 training images. The network architecture, the optimizer, and the number of local training epochs are set to the options used in Sec. F.2.1.

F.3 Connection probability setup in Fig. 4.1

In Fig. 4.1, we select different connection probabilities p=p⋆​(n,qtotal)𝑝superscript𝑝⋆𝑛subscript𝑞totalp=p^{\star}(n,q_{\text{total}}) for various n𝑛n and qtotalsubscript𝑞totalq_{\text{total}}, where p⋆superscript𝑝⋆p^{\star} is defined in (5). The detailed values of connection probability p𝑝p are provided in Table F.4.

F.4 Running time experiment in Table 5.1

We implemented the CCESA algorithm in python. For symmetric authenticated encryption, we use AES-GCM with 128-bit keys in Crypto.Cipher package. For the pseudorandom generator, we use randint function (input: random seed, output: random integer in the field of size 216superscript2162^{16}) in numpy.random package. For key agreement, we use Elliptic-Curve Diffie-Hellman over the NIST SP800-56 curve composed with a SHA-256 hash function. For secret sharing, we use standard t𝑡t-out-of-n𝑛n secret sharing (Shamir, 1979).
